content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::AbstractString)
    questions = Vector{String}()
    answers = Vector{String}()
    current_section = :none

    for line in split(md, "\n")
        if occursin("# Question", line)
            if current_section != :question
                push!(questions, strip(line))
                current_section = :question
            end
        elseif occursin("# Answer", line)
            if current_section != :answer
                push!(answers, strip(line))
                current_section = :answer
            end
        elseif current_section == :question
            push!(questions, "\n" * strip(line))
        elseif current_section == :answer
            push!(answers, "\n" * strip(line))
        end
    end

    return (questions[1], answers[1]) # Assuming only one question and answer per document
end
```

This function works by iterating over each line in the markdown text and keeping track of the current section (`:question` or `:answer`). When it encounters a `# Question` line, it starts collecting the question text. Similarly, when it sees a `# Answer` line, it starts collecting the answer text. Both questions and answers are stored as lists until the end of the document is reached. Finally, the first element from each list is returned as the tuple `(question, answer)`.
